item.title: Win a copy of Ajax in Action or a T-Shirt
item.description:
Win a copy of Ajax in Action or a T-Shirt

For everyone that has been reading my blog, I thought that I would share the contest I got started with the support of Manning and JavaRanch. We want you to help us create the slogan for our Ajax in Action T-Shirt! Below is the contest email that was sent out in the JavaRanch newsletter. If you are not a current member, sign on up!

Eric Pascarello

Contest Details:
If you can not come up with a slogan, you still have a chance to win a t-shirt! Manning would love to hear what you think about Ajax, what it means to you, how you have implemented it, and so on. Our resident moderator and co-author of Ajax in Action, Eric Pascarello, will be in the HTML and JavaScript forum like always to answer any questions you may have about Ajax or Ajax In Action. Get your thinking caps on and start coming up with your best slogan ideas!

You can take a look at the description of the book here:

http://www.manning.com/books/crane

Read about the book, come up with a catchy slogan suitable for t-shirts and post it in our HTML and JavaScript forum:

http://saloon.javaranch.com/cgi-bin/ubb/ultimatebb.cgi?ubb=get_topic&f=20&t=004837

Legal stuff: All entries (no matter how awful) become the property of Manning. Contest Ends Friday, August 26th at midnight MST.

item.title: Sending XML to the Sever with AJAX
item.description:
Sending XML to the Sever with AJAX
A question that has come up to lately by people on JavaRanch and emails I received is how do I send an XML to the server using Ajax. It is possible to send an XML document in the request parameter. One thing you need to make sure is that you set the header correctly to text/xml and post the document to the server. This following is a basic example that highlights the fact that we are not limited to just sending query string and form values to the server, which seems to be implanted into certain developerâ€™s minds.
